Tony Doyle, Jane Lapotaire, Mark Dignam, Nicol Williamson, James Hazeldine, Jon Rowe, Gawn Grainger, Ian Hogg, Brenda Bruce, Eileen Way, Anne Dyson, Gordon Kane, James Bolam, Christopher Ellison, Tom Bowles, Jill Baker and Crispin Mair.

Nicol Williamson is MacBeth and Jane Lapotaire Lady MacBeth in this BBC production of Shakespeare's tragic masterpiece. Williamson and Lapotaire make MacBeth and his lady an decidedly eccentric, neurotic pair. Williamson brings his trademark almost whimsically unusual line readings to the role, while Lapotaire's Lady MacBeth is played with moments that almost seem like orgiastic parody. Mark Dignam is Duncan, James Hazeldine is Malcolm, Jon Rowe is Lennox, Gawn Grainger is Ross, Ian Hogg as Banquo. Also With: Brenda Bruce as the first witch, Eileen Way as the second witch, Anne Dyson as the third witch, Gordon Kane as First Messenger, James Bolam as Porter, Christopher Ellison as a captain, Tom Bowles as Donalbain, Jill Baker as Lady MacDuff, and Crispin Mair as MacDuff's son.
A dramatization of William Shakespeare's tragedy entitled Macbeth.

This interpretation of MacBeth sparked an unusual amount of controversy for a production of Shakespeare. It is a violent film, full of kinetic, disturbing images of death and dying -- decapitations and brutal swordplay abound. Many interpreted the violence as an effort by the director to strike back at the public, especially the American public, for the horrible death of his wife, Sharon Tate, and others in the Manson slaughters. Whether that assessment has any validity or not is irrelevant to the fact that this version of MacBeth is actually thrilling to watch. The decision to go with young attractive actors in the roles of MacBeth and Lady MacBeth was a good one. Jon Finch is properly ambitious and brutish as the traitorous Lord. Francesca Annis is a lovely Lady MacBeth especially in the moments when her guilt makes her become distracted. A lot was made of the fact that Hugh Hefner and Playboy magazine produced the film. That too doesn't matter. The gore and noise and minor eroticism of the film does nothing to denigrate the play and is obviously closer to the reality of a violent, semi-barbaric epoch in history. The violence first netted the film an X rating by the MPAA. A few scenes were cut to have the rating changed.

Nicol Williamson is MacBeth and Jane Lapotaire Lady MacBeth in this BBC production of Shakespeare's tragic masterpiece. Williamson and Lapotaire make MacBeth and his lady an decidedly eccentric, neurotic pair. Williamson brings his trademark almost whimsically unusual line readings to the role, while Lapotaire's Lady MacBeth is played with moments that almost seem like orgiastic parody. Mark Dignam is Duncan, James Hazeldine is Malcolm, Jon Rowe is Lennox, Gawn Grainger is Ross, Ian Hogg as Banquo. Using Shakespeare's classic text, this television production of Macbeth is set in a timeless zone somewhere in the twentieth century against a raw, urban industrial environment. The film is notable for a carefully edited text which enables students to explore the playwright's handling of passion, murderous fury, betrayal and guilt.

A lavish Chinese epic, set in the Age of Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms, tells the story of a royal court in turmoil: forbidden love, deceit, revenge, overpowering beauty, and greed. A young empress finds her empire on the verge of a massive revolution as storms begin to brew both within the royal court as well as in the outlying kingdoms. She turns to her stepson for assistance but finds herself deeply involved in an attempt to have her throne and power overtaken. The film is heavily influenced by Shakespeare's plays, specifically Hamlet and Macbeth.
DVD-9; NTSC; all regions; anamorphic widescreen (16:9, enhanced) presentation; Dolby Digital 5.1 surround and DTS 96/24.

Adaptation of Shakespeare's Macbeth, set in feudal Japan. Tells the story of a Samurai lord who kills his master and usurps his power in fulfillment of a witch's prophecy.

Based on the play "The tragedy of Macbeth" by William Shakespeare.
Originally released as a motion picture in 1971.
Director of photography, Gil Taylor ; editor, Alastair McIntyre ; original music, Third Ear Band ; costume designer, Anthony Mendleson ; production designer, Wilfrid Shingleton.
Jon Finch, Francesca Annis, Nicholas Selby, Martin Shaw, Terence Bayler, John Stride, Stephen Chase, Paul Shelley.

A classic tragedy about the lust for power and its ultimate bloody consequences. Macbeth is a Scottish war hero whose insane ambition unleashes a cycle of violence. Prompted by the supernatural prophecy of three witches, Macbeth is then goaded by his lady into slaying King Duncan in order to assume the throne. He plunges further into murder and moral decay to keep the unsteady crown on his head.
English dialogue, Portuguese or Spanish subtitles.

Eleventh century Scottish nobleman Macbeth is led by an evil prophecy and his ruthless yet desirable wife to the treasonous act that makes him king. But he does not enjoy his newfound, dearly-won kingship.
